utterances: If there's a hero in this story, it is Esther Kutto, principal of Dabaso Primary School in the beach resort of Watamu.
Her teachers act like social workers.
If they notice a girl has dropped out of school, they go looking for her.
And if they find that the girl has been married off or sold to a white foreigner, they notify the police.
Like the Kaya elders, Kutto educates her students' parents that early marriage is wrong.
They did not know even what the rights of the children were.
But now that we are teaching the children of their rights, they also in turn go to teach their parents about their rights.
In fact, one of the basic rights of the young children is education.
Kutto says underage pregnancies at her school have dropped from 29 in 2009 to five so far this year.
So passionate is the principal about saving girls from early marriage that, two years ago, she repaid a bride price of $70 for one of her students who had been married off.
She snatched the teenager away from the indignant husband and brought her back to school.
She's about to graduate and Esther Kutto expects her to become an advocate to convince other girls to take a stand against early marriage and sexual exploitation.
John Burnett, NPR News, Nairobi.
NPR's Scott Horsley reports.
President Obama was asked about Bank of America's new fee during an interview with ABC.
He seemed to suggest the fee could become a target for the federal government's new financial watchdog agency.
This is exactly why we need this Consumer Finance Protection Bureau that we set up, that is ready to go.
Bank of America said in a statement that the loss of those fees is costing it billions of dollars a year and the new fee is designed to recoup some of that.
Vice President Nessa Feddis of the American Bankers' Association says, so long as the Durbin Amendment is in place, B of A won't be the only bank to experiment with additional charges.
When a government intrudes and imposes price controls, the natural response is for any business to find a way to replace that lost income and that's what we're seeing with the Durbin Amendment.
It's doubtful the new Consumer Protection Bureau has the authority to actually stop B of A or any other bank from charging the new fee, but Mr. Obama argued the banks should reconsider.

If you say to the banks, you don't have some inherent right just to, you know, get a certain amount of profit if your customers are being mistreated, that you have to treat them fairly and transparently, and my hope is that you're going to see a bunch of the banks who say to themselves, you know what, this is actually not good business practice.
Illinois Senator Dick Durbin, whose amendment limited the old invisible fees, was more blunt in his advice for customers who want to avoid any additional charges.
Bank of America customers, vote with your feet.
Get the heck out of that bank.
Find yourself a bank or credit union that won't gouge you for $5 a month and still will give you a debit card that you can use every single day.
But that may be easier said than done.
Jean Ann Fox of the Consumer Federation of America says customers who rely on direct deposit or electronic bill paying services may find it harder to switch banks.
There is effort involved in closing one account and opening another one.
And I think banks have counted on how much trouble that is and that that would be a disincentive for you to switch accounts.
But first, NPR political editor Ken Rudin joins us and Ken will get to the big night for Congressional Democrats in a minute and undecided races.

But from the beginning, Barack Obama vowed to do two things in this campaign, to expand the electorate, to get a lot of people to vote who never did before, and expand the map to put Republicans on the defensive by making them fight for the states that they've come to take for granted.
And he did both, and he did both amazingly, successfully.

I mean, he - I mean, I was to say, he only got 52 percent of the vote, not a popular vote landslide, but electoral counts landslide, 349 electoral votes as we speak, not including North Carolina, which he may ultimately pull out and win.

But the fact is, is that with all that money, with all those - the registration of new voters, with the excitement of electorate, with lines around the block, he picked up states that haven't voted Democratic in decades: Virginia not since 1964, Indiana since 1964, Missouri is still too close to call which is pretty remarkable, Florida, another state.

It was early on the evening, once Barack Obama won Pennsylvania, that was really the blue state that John McCain really hoped to get, and once he took Ohio, then people said, well, it's just a matter of time and it became a matter of time because it started counting (unintelligible).
I just want to say one thing though.
We spent the last, you know, last night spending all these hours going over house races and counties and bellwether counties.

I'm not really getting a real grade - it wasn't until this morning when I had like two or three hours of sleep and suddenly it just - it came to me the enormity of what happened, the c-change of what happened yesterday.
It's not just states that have gone from red to blue, but it's just people's opinions, their attitudes, it just seemed to change in a blink of an eye.
Yet, there were an awful lot of people who voted for the Republican candidate and not for that kind of change, obviously he was campaigning for changes.
Well, nevertheless, take us back two years.
We had an on-going argument within the Democratic Party between Rahm Emanuel, then running the Democratic Congressional Committee, and Howard Dean, the Democratic National Committee chairman.

Howard Dean wanted to run a 50-state strategy to put money in unlikely places like Montana and the Dakotas and Alaska, of all places, to build the party up, while Rahm Emanuel said, we have a real chance to win control of Congress this year.
We need to focus on races where we can win.
And both actually were correct.
Rahm Emanuel said they have a chance of winning control of Congress in 2006 and they did so.
They toppled long time Republican incumbents, long time Republican held districts in 2006.
But Howard Dean said, look, it's not just the 14 states we keep competing in every year John Kerry and Al Gore compete in these 14 states.
You have to broaden the electorate, you have to broaden the map.
And so, we saw in special elections and Congress, Democrats winning Congressional seats in Mississippi, in Louisiana, Dennis Hastert's seat in Illinois.
There were a lot of expanding of the electorate, and both plans, the Emanuel position and the Howard Dean position came to flourish on last night.
A lot of argument for nothing.
That's right.

And of course, Rahm Emanuel reports say that he has been named or has been offered the position as chief of staff to Barack Obama, which is interesting because Emanuel was never a big Obama supporter.
He's actually stayed on the sidelines because he had loyalty to Hillary Clinton as well.
He was, of course, in the White House as an adviser to Bill Clinton 12 years ago.
Anyway, as we go back over, there's still some races to be decided.
You mentioned North Carolina and Missouri still out in the presidential campaign and there's a number of Senate races that have yet to be decided.
Right, there's four in the Senate and Minnesota is one of them.
Nearly three million votes have been cast right now.
Norm Coleman, the incumbent Republican has a 727 vote lead that is an automatic recount.
He's going against comedian, Democrat Al Franken.
It was a third party candidate, Dean Barkley, who got 15 percent of the vote.
That is an automatic recount that may not be decided until December.
Although, Republicans have already congratulated Coleman for winning re-election.
In Georgia, Saxby Chambliss, the first term Republican, does have the most votes, but you need a majority.
State law in Georgia says you have to have a majority.
Right now, Chambliss has 49.8 percent of the vote and that means it would go to a December 2nd run-off with Democrat Jim Martin.
That was a surprise, a lot of people thought that Chambliss would be able to eek out a victory.
Obviously, the African-American vote was crucial in Georgia.
In Alaska, 96 percent of the vote in as we speak.
Ted Stevens is - Ted Stevens, remember him?
Yeah.
The convicted on seven felony counts.
Like two weeks before election.
Exactly, 84 years old, the longest serving Republican in the history of the Senate.
He's up by 3,400 votes, maybe 97, 98 percent of the vote in.
There's still 40,000 absentee votes left to be counted.
But a lot of people say that he could actually win.
Now, remember John McCain, Sarah Palin, Mitch McConnell of the Republican League of the Senate all said that Ted Stevens should resign and resign immediately.
It's possible here, we go with these theories here, but it's possible that Ted Stevens could win and then be forced to resign and resign and what's - the woman from Alaska, what's.
There's Governor Sarah Palin.
Sarah Palin.
Sarah Palin could theoretically run in a special election, and she can come to Washington and torment all the Democrats who, you know, who've been tormenting her in this election.
Finally, in Oregon, only three quarters of the vote has counted so far.
As you know in Oregon, it's a male only ballot.
So, obviously women cannot vote in Oregon because it's male only.
I've used that joke 12 times in this show.
Gordon Smith has a slight lead, 48 to 46 percent of the vote.
Sixty-two thousand votes in Oregon was taken by a third party candidate.
If Gordon Smith loses to Jeff Merkley, it was a third party conservative who caused him his victory.
But right now, he has a slight lead.
And let's see if we can - we'll be bringing you up to date on those, but it could be weeks before we know the outcome here.
That's absolutely true.
Certainly the case in Georgia, remember the last time this happened, Wyche Fowler in 1992 had a lead in the Georgia Senate race but didn't get a majority.
They went to a December run-off and the Republican Coverdell won that seat.
So, you know that if the Democrats have this momentum of wind in their sails in December, there can be tons of money thrown into that run-off in Georgia.
Well, it's Andy who's assiduous and Ken who's the other one, anyway.
We want to get some callers in on this conversation.
Again, McCain supporters, give us a call at 800-344-3893.
Obama backers, 800-344-3864.
And let's go to the phones.
This is Mike.
Mike with us from Milwaukee in Wisconsin on the Republican line.
Excuse me, on the Democratic line, I apologize.
Yes.
Hi, Ken and Neal.
Thanks for taking my call.
Go ahead please.

Just wanted to say very quickly that this was the triumph of the rational decision making of candidates like Barack Obama who are thoughtful, intelligent, cautious, and they listen to people who don't agree with them, and I reflected as well over the sub-rational decision making of presidents like President Bush who is - who looked into the eyes of a former KDV agent and had a gut feeling that this guy would be a close friend.
But also of Senator John McCain who had a gut feeling about Governor Palin.
He said, that's my vice president instead of rationally and very adequately vetting her.
But also, too, he's rather impulsive as well as a gut feeling selection of sub-rational selection of Joe the Plumber.
If he was vetted properly, he would have found out that Joe didn't even have a plumber's license.
And if I could say very quickly, I'm somewhat dismayed at Joe the Plumber, too, for his lack of ambition and falsely identifying of himself.
Wow.
He didn't have a doctor's license.
He may as well call himself Joe the Doctor.
Thank you very much.
All right, Mike.
Thanks very much for the call.
The sub-rational - that's Mike's way of characterizing it.

Yet, we're hearing some analysis today, Ken, that the McCain campaign lurched from issue to issue, made some mistakes including the selection of Governor Palin as vice presidential candidate - excited the base, but cost them a lot of votes in the center.
Well, if the goal was to win independent and disaffect the Democrats, obviously, Sarah Palin didn't do that.

But at the same time, John McCain knew from the beginning he had to build up his base among the conservatives who never trusted him to begin with and the thought, of course, at that time with Sarah Palin.
One thing about Mike's call, though, that's exactly right, I've never seen a flawless campaign as I saw with Barack Obama.
He just never made a mistake, never lost his cool and just, you know, took everything as it came and he just showed it last night.
Let's go to the Republican line now.
This is Josh and Josh is with us from Woodbury in Minnesota.
Hi.

I just want to say how important I think it is that - I mean, I was - I voted for McCain and I think it's important that we - instead of worrying about - and McCain said himself in his concession speech.
Instead of worrying about who won or who lost, now the teams are dissolved.
We don't have teams anymore now we're all Americans again, and so we need to work together in - regardless of who we voted for.

And I guess the only concern that I have - one main concern about President-Elect Obama is that he backed himself into a corner with the promises he made about Iraq and may make some policy decisions that aren't - that won't respect the lives of the troops that have been lost and the time that the troops has spent and their dedication.
We have yet to see what Senator - excuse me, President-Elect Obama will do about the situation in Iraq.
The United States is in the process of negotiating a status of forces agreement with the government in Iraq.
If it should be ratified before he takes office on January 20th, it would - well, to some degree, tie his hands in terms of the outer limit of an American withdraw.
He would want to withdraw perhaps more quickly than that.
But quickly, Ken, what could you say about a gracious speech last night by Senator McCain?
Both McCain and Obama gave very, very gracious speeches.
But I suspect that the pragmatism of Barack Obama will come through in his promises about Iraq and spending in taxes.
I suspect there'll be some changing from the campaign rhetoric to what actually happens in the early days of the administration.
Thanks very much for the call, Josh.
Thank you.
And again, we're asking McCain supporters to call us at 800-344-3893.
Obama backers at 800-344-3864.
Ken is going to stay with us.
When we come back from a short break, we'll be joined by Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press, as we continue to talk about who won where and why.
I'm Neal Conan.
Stay with us.
It's a day after election special from NPR News.
